text: The ubiquitous octamer - binding protein ( s ) is sufficient for transcription of immunoglobulin genes .
All immunoglobulin genes contain a conserved octanucleotide promoter element , ATGCAAAT , which has been shown to be required for their normal B-cell - specific transcription .
Proteins that bind this octamer have been purified , and cDNAs encoding octamer - binding proteins have been cloned .

Some of these proteins ( referred to as <extra_id_0> OTF-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) are lymphoid specific , whereas at least one other , and possibly more ( referred to as <extra_id_0> OTF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , is found ubiquitously in all cell types .
The exact role of these different proteins in directing the tissue - specific expression of immunoglobulin genes is unclear .

We have identified two human pre-B-cell lines that contain extremely low levels of <extra_id_0> OTF-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> yet still express high levels of steady-state immunoglobulin heavy-chain mRNA in vivo and efficiently transcribe an immunoglobulin gene in vitro .

Addition of a highly enriched preparation of <extra_id_0> OTF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> made from one of these pre-B cells or from HeLa cells specifically stimulated in vitro transcription of an immunoglobulin gene .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> OFT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> appeared to have approximately the same transactivation ability as <extra_id_0> OTF-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> when normalized for binding activity .

text: These results suggest that <extra_id_0> OTF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , without <extra_id_0> OTF-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is sufficient for transcription of immunoglobulin genes and that <extra_id_0> OTF-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone is not responsible for the B-cell - specific regulation of immunoglobulin gene expression .
